How to Build with Universal Design

These are practical steps you can plug into your normal dev workflow. No magic frameworks needed—just thoughtful HTML, CSS, and testing.

1. Start mobile-first

  • Design for small screens first, then scale up.
  • Use fluid widths (%, rem, etc.) instead of fixed pixels where possible.
  • Keep layouts simple and readable with enough spacing.

2. Use semantic HTML

  • Use <header>, <nav>, <main>, <footer>, and headings in order.
  • Ensure there is only one <h1> per page that describes the main topic.
  • Use lists for groups of related items and descriptive button/link text.

3. Check color and type

  • Pick colors with enough contrast between text and background.
  • Use font sizes that don’t require zooming to be readable.
  • Avoid huge blocks of text with no headings or breaks.

4. Make it keyboard-friendly

  • Test your site using only the Tab, Shift+Tab, and Enter keys.
  • Make sure focus indicators are visible (don’t remove the outline).
  • Avoid any component that can only be used with a mouse or touch.

5. Describe your media

  • Add alt text to images that actually explains their purpose.
  • Use captions or transcripts for audio and video when possible.
  • Don’t rely on color alone to communicate meaning.

6. Test with real tools

Before you call a project “done,” run:

  • An HTML validator for broken structure.
  • A color contrast checker.
  • An accessibility checker (like WAVE or browser dev tools).
